articles.headline: Afghan War’s Buried Bombs Put Risk in Every Step
articles.snippet: The insurgency’s improvised explosive devices are becoming more common and sophisticated each week.
articles.abstract: The insurgency’s improvised explosive devices are becoming more common and sophisticated each week.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE ALTIMUR, Afghanistan  The call came just after dinner: a pickup truck carrying Afghan national police officers had hit a buried bomb, and all five officers inside were dead.

articles.headline: Intel’s Results Give Hope to Industry
articles.snippet: The chip company reported second-quarter sales of $8 billion, which analysts say indicate how well the overall computer industry is doing.
articles.abstract: The chip company reported second-quarter sales of $8 billion, which analysts say indicate how well the overall computer industry is doing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The darkest time in the personal computer industry’s history may have ended.

articles.headline: Part-Time Workers Mask Unemployment Woes
articles.snippet: In California and other states, one out of every five people who would like to be working full time is not doing so.
articles.abstract: In California and other states, one out of every five people who would like to be working full time is not doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: In California and a handful of other states, one out of every five people who would like to be working full time is not now doing so.

articles.headline: Calpers Sues Over Ratings of Securities
articles.snippet: The public pension fund has filed suit in California in connection with $1 billion in losses that it says were caused by “wildly inaccurate” credit ratings from the three leading ratings agencies.
articles.abstract: The public pension fund has filed suit in California in connection with $1 billion in losses that it says were caused by “wildly inaccurate” credit ratings from the three leading ratings agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO  The nation’s largest public pension fund has filed suit in California state court in connection with $1 billion in losses that it says were caused by “wildly inaccurate” credit ratings from the three leading ratings agencies.

articles.headline: To Shrink a U.S. Car, Chrysler Goes to Poland
articles.snippet: Engineers from Chrysler, looking for guidance, have been visiting a Fiat plant in Poland that is churning out autos and profits.
articles.abstract: Engineers from Chrysler, looking for guidance, have been visiting a Fiat plant in Poland that is churning out autos and profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYCHY, Poland  For decades, automakers looking for the secret to small-car success would journey to Toyota City in Japan. These days, they are coming to Tychy.

articles.headline: Germany Has Been Slow to Fix Its Banks
articles.snippet: Companies want to be prepared when the global economy rebounds, but say lenders are squeezing them on credit.
articles.abstract: Companies want to be prepared when the global economy rebounds, but say lenders are squeezing them on credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Farhad Farassat, a Munich-based entrepreneur, blames fickle banks for his difficulty getting a loan. But, like many Germans, his problem may be largely political.

articles.headline: Derivatives Are Focus of Antitrust Investigators
articles.snippet: Markit, a data warehouse controlled by several big banks, said it had been notified that it was the subject of an inquiry.
articles.abstract: Markit, a data warehouse controlled by several big banks, said it had been notified that it was the subject of an inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is investigating the role of several major companies in the credit markets, in another indication that the government is intensifying its scrutiny of derivatives,

articles.headline: Mortgages Are Now a Bank’s Best Friend
articles.snippet: Mortgages have switched from a bane to a boon for banks in the second quarter because of a refinancing wave.
articles.abstract: Mortgages have switched from a bane to a boon for banks in the second quarter because of a refinancing wave.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last two years, housing has been at the center of the banking industry’s troubles. But for at least one quarter, it will help lift its results.
